results.title: Spitfire 123
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, monitors, colour and audio
results.brief_description: The third in an ongoing six-part series collectively titled ‘From the Darwin Translations’. This series, like Jones’ previous projects, shifts between installation, video, and performance, in an exploration of human (sexual) attraction. The installation spans two rooms, one with a large screen and another with three video monitors. The monitor room shows a more meditative, transitional space, ‘poppy fields’; a repeating image series of swaying poppies, accompanied by the rustle of wind, bird song and insect noises and interrupted now and then by the roar of airplanes flying overhead. The large screen in the other room presents, ‘Spitfire’, showing shots from the cockpit of the legendary World War II fighter plane, accompanied by engine-sounds, dramatic computerized noises and oscillating-music, as well as whispering voices. Sky and land spiral, falter, and blur as intimate fantasies are imparted. Thus the result is fragmented and disorientating. The position of the audience shifts between that of voyeur and that of participant. She threatens to undo you with the romance of memory, aeroplanes and youth; you have to look, listen and feel.

results.title: Platform 1
results.brief_description: As a visitor descends the stairway into the Screen Gallery, her path will leave a trace through which imagery will emerge from the past — people ascending from a train platform in Australia one hundred years ago. The artwork is a live interplay between the present and the past. As ACMI visitors descend the stairs to encounter the future of screen arts, they pass through the lingering and ever-present influence of cinematic history. A wondrous, benign space of haunting, the staircase initiates Screen Gallery visitors into the ever-present power of cinematic history.

results.title: Hold: Vessel #1 and Vessel #2
results.material_description: mixed media, interactive video, projection, glass, colour and sound
results.brief_description:
Hold: Vessel 1 is a magical interactive experience in which visitors to the gallery try to catch a mesmerizing series of projected visions in a delicate glass bowl - echoing the wondrous views of the world made possible with the first microscopes, underwater cameras and astronomical cinematography.
Lynette Wallworth began her career in photography, and has also worked in short film, installation and performance. She creates installation spaces that require activation by the participant/viewer. To collect the images used in Hold: Vessel 1 she collaborated with scientific image libraries and specialist cinematographers, as part of her ongoing investigation into imaging technologies that enable us to see the world in ways otherwise inaccessible to the naked human eye. Hold: Vessel 1 consists of video projections with directional sound scape beamed from above into a darkened space. The visitor is invited to take hold of a glass bowl and catch the images within it, finding the point at which the vision is most clear and resolved. A personal portal opens to us as we cradle the bowl in our hands. Imagery in ‘Hold’ is derived mainly from Australian scientists and specialist cinematographers including: David Hannan, who has adapted medical imaging technology to film extreme macro images of the Great Barrier Reef, Anya Salih, who investigates coral fluorescence and Greg Rouse, Marine Biologist. The work is designed as a vessel to hold a changing pool of imagery. Hold: Vessel 1 will change in time as time changes the environments it reflects.

results.title: Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion [exhibition] : archival material
results.brief_description:
“Deep Space: Sensation & Immersion” was an ACMI Screen Gallery Exhibition, held 26 October 2002 - 27 January 2003.
See Exhibition activity record “Deep Space” (ID 3) for more information
The international and Australian contemporary artists in this exibition present environments, or chambers, for the visitor to participate in an all encompassing aesthetic experience. The audience is invited to move within the art works, to explore their physical construction, their digital presence, their filmic pulse and their saturated expanses of colour and light. The experiences vary: some are quiet, some intangible, others humourous or uncanny. Each involves an ephemeral medium, whether it be light, video or digital imagery and each encloses the viewer in a confined space only to offer them access to another expanded sense of space altogether. This exhibition offers visitors a memorable and transformative experience of being immersed in ‘deep space’, the kineasthetic, visual, aural and informational totality of the art works.

results.title: Buried in light
results.brief_description: In this work originally commissioned as a multi-screen installation, Cohen meditates on ‘a time between times’ as he travels through Central and Eastern Europe. The filmmaker invests his own dreamily elegiac images of sites of past horror and devastation with ‘found’ commentaries taken from radio announcers and museum guides. With a considered use of archival material, Cohen restores a deep and affecting agency to the ghosts of the past, even as he signals a concern with the encroaching signs of change being wrought on contemporary European societies. A lightness emerges, ultimately, in Cohen’s visually poetic and spiritually consoling ‘seven possibilities for colour beyond advertising’; a wry melancholy postscript the filmmaker proposes as a parting gift.

results.title: [Cinesound Review 1950-1965]
results.brief_description:
This film contains excerpts from Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The film features a number of different clips from newsreels between 1950 and 1965.

The first section, titled ‘1950 Melbourne Cup’, shows the horse race at Flemington Racecourse, photographed by Ron Horner. The film includes close-ups of people in the crowd, and commentary of the race as Comic Court wins. This is followed by a section titled ‘Scone Rodeo: Bronchos (sic) on the Bust’, featuring footage of a horse rodeo in Scone, New South Wales.

The third section, titled ‘Fur Flies: Battling Budgerigar K.O.’s Cat’ features a playfight between two pets, a ginger cat and a budgerigar. In the fourth section we see ANZAC Day parades in Melbourne and Sydney, preluded by the title ‘ANZAC: Nation’s Homage’.

The fifth section is titled ‘Skiing: Day and Night Fun at Mt. Buller’, with commentary by David Low. It features children learning how to ski and social activities in the resorts, including bands and dancing. This is followed by an excerpt called ‘Clark Well Ahead’, showing the motorcar race at the 1965 British Grand Prix, won by Jim Clark.

The film ends with a cartoon called ‘Local Boy Makes Good: A Story with a Moral’ and three feature film trailers: ‘The Counterfeit Traitor’ (1962), ‘Pollyanna’ (1960) and ‘Mein Kampf’ (1960).

results.title: Closure
results.brief_description: A young girl reflects on her connections with her family and friends and she attempts to discover why she feels like she is being ignored. She focuses on the experiences from her past but continually feels an intrinsic connection to water. Only later does she discover why this is the case.

results.title: The Mansion [game trailer]
results.brief_description: It’s a moonless night… Let’s go explore a mansion. In ‘The Mansion’, a nameless character finds himself with the task of searching an old mansion. Although he can’t understand the lost children it doesn’t take a true connection to know only he can help. The story is told through a platformer format, inspired by games such as Super Mario Bros.

results.title: The Tank Gang: A Say No to Bullies Story
results.creator_credit: Willem Durrand, Tahalia Durrand and Ruben Durrand
results.brief_description: This is the story of the Tank Gang. The Tank Gang love playing together, even with Jack, the bully. One day, Jack goes too far and the Tank Gang see how putting up with Jack has meant that their friend got hurt. The friends all learn the importance of standing up for each other, not bullying and being good friends.

results.title: Max's Farm
results.brief_description: Max is a perfectionist. He loves his farm and wants it to be the best. The ‘Farmer’s Weekly’ arrives and his farm rates 27th. That’s a great score, but Max wants it number 1. He tries to improve his farm by eliminating what he thinks are pests, but that just makes his farm worse. He has to find out how to get things work together.
